title: ’13 Hours’ Makes Oscars News In A Way No One Expected
text:
George Clooney Says Trump And Steve Bannon Are ‘Hollywood Elitists’ 
Although Russell was booted off, the Oscar nomination in the sound mixing category remained alive for 13 Hours ‘ other sound mixers — Gary Summers, Jeffrey Haboush and Mac Ruth. 
The film, however, lost out in the sound mixing category to another movie about a dramatic military encounter — Hacksaw Ridge . 
Russell had called members of the Academy’s Sound Branch “to make them aware of his work on the film, in direct violation of a campaign regulation that prohibits telephone lobbying,” according to an Academy statement. Advertisement - story continues below 
“The Board of Governors’ decision to rescind Mr. Russell’s nomination was made after careful consideration,” said Academy President Cheryl Boone Isaacs in a statement. “The Academy takes very seriously the Oscars voting process and anything — no matter how well-intentioned — that may undermine the integrity of that process.” 
The Academy board determined that Russell’s actions “violated a campaign regulation that unequivocally prohibits telephone lobbying,” according to the release. This regulation states that “contacting Academy members by telephone to promote a film or achievement is expressly forbidden, even if such contact is in the guise of checking to make sure a screener or other mailing was received.” 
Although Russell remains winless after 17 sound nominations, Sunday’s awards did put an Oscar in the hands of another long-time nominee who had never won before. 
“I can’t even tell you the experience it was for me,” said sound mixer Kevin O’Connell , who was one of the four men honored for their work on Hacksaw Ridge and who had been nominated 20 times without winning. “As much as I thought I knew what it would feel like [to win], I didn’t. It was the greatest feeling in my entire life.” Advertisement - story continues below
